lines.text: Mam called me barmy when I told her I fell of a gasometer for a bet. But I'm not barmy, I'm a fighting pit prop that wants a pint of beer, that's me. But if any knowing bastard says that's me I'll tell them I'm a dynamite dealer waiting to blow the factory to kingdom come. I'm me and nobody else. Whatever people say I am, that's what I'm not because they don't know a bloody thing about me! God knows what I am.
Don't let the bastards grind you down!
What I'm out for is a good time - all the rest is propaganda!
[last lines]
What did you do that for?
I don't know, just felt like it I suppose.
Maybe one of those houses will be for us.
I know.
You shouldn't throw things like that.
It won't be the last one I'll throw. C'mon duck, let's go down!
They have a television set and a packet of fags, but they're both dead from the neck up.
[first lines]
Nine hundred and fifty four, nine hundred and fifty bloody five. Another few more and that's the lot for a Friday.
I'll have a fag in a bit, no use working every minute God sends. I could get through in half the time if I went like a bull, but they'd only slash my wages so they can get stuffed!
I believe you, thousands wouldn't.
Eight pints already, he's having a good time innit he!
Sharp, ain't he.
Is it somebody's birthday?
It's Mum's anniversary if you want to know.
I can't see your dad.
That's because he's not there.
Well, is he coming?
I shouldn't think so, he left her 15 years ago today and she's just having a drink on it.
[laughs]
Well I'm glad someone thinks it's funny.
What's your name then duck?
Doreen, rotten name ain't it.
What's wrong with it? Mine's Arthur, neither of them's up to much but it's not our fault, is it.
What do you do in the week Doreen, do you ever go to pictures?
Only on Wednesday, why?
That's funny, I go on Wednesday n'all. Which one you go to?
The Granby, as a rule
I'll see you next Wednesday then at 7.
Fast worker aren't you. All right, but not on the back row.
I noticed that girl myself this morning, smashing bit of stuff. I shouldn't think she'd want aught to do with a madhead like you though.
They all want a good time you can bet.
Brother home for long?

Fortnight. There's one thing about him though, you know, he'll always help me if I'm in any sort of trouble. If anyone does aught against me, I can always rely on him. I was with him and his pal once and we set on a bloke... I never want to do aught like that again.

Aye but people like that should be careful though, never to pick on the wrong bloke. I saw a fight like that once, this was with two soldiers an' all. They set on to a bloke and he wiped the floor with the both of them. It was horrible, blood all over the place, I had to turn me 'ead away.
Think of number one, share and share alike's no good.
You wouldn't think like that though if you won the pools though, would you?
Wouldn't I? I'd see the family right but nobody else. If I got a stack of begging letters like most blokes do, you know what I'd do with them?
What?
Make a bonfire.
It's not the first time that bastard's called me a red though. Not that I wouldn't vote communist if I thought it would get rid of blokes like him.
That's what all these looney laws are for, to be broken by blokes like us.
You might cop it one of these days.
Of all the liars, you're the biggest I've ever known.
I always was a liar, a good 'un and all.
Liars don't prosper.
Hey Arthur, what a time we had last night.
It seems years... aye you're lovely Brenda.
Pour us some more tea duck, it's thirsty work falling down stairs.
Two ain't it.
You're good to me Brenda, love, and don't think I don't appreciate it.
I dunno, work next week. I'll be hard at it, sweating me guts out at that lathe. It's a hard life if you don't weaken.
He settled her though, threatened to chuck her off Trent Bridge.
Oh aye, I'd forgot that.
She thought it were better to settle for a quid a week out of court rather than get a good wash.
You should have been with us.
Our Ethel clicked with a bloke and he bought us drinks all round, the whole gang of us.
Aye, he must have got through a good 5 quid, soft bastard. Still he had a car so I suppose he could afford it.
You can't beat a bit of fun, can you Arthur.
How's Johnny getting on in Australia?
Well you know Arthur, I reckon Johnny's a lot better off out there, he never did well in this country, did he.
No, he always was a good worker though, I know that.
Them was rotten days.
I know, it won't happen again though, I can tell you that.

I was talking to a bloke the other day at the pit, he's always going on you know 'you can't beat the good old days'. So I got 'old of me pick and I said to him - 'you tell me anything else about them good old days as you call them and I'll split your stupid head open' - I would too.
I take a tip from the fishes, never bite unless the bait's good. I won't get married till I'm good and ready.
Look at him, he can't take his eyes off that young girl over there.
Not me, I'm courting already. I was looking at the calendar.
I believe you.
What's that black stuff you're drinking, it looks like treacle.
Beer and stout, try a drop.
No thanks, I think I tasted it once but it was horrible.
Well, I'm not a boozer either but I'm going fishing this afternoon and I like a drop beforehand.
Where do you work then Doreen?
Me? Harrison's, the hairnet factory, I've been there ever since I left school.
It costs too much to get married, a lump sum down and your wages a week for life.
Most blokes ain't got aught else to work for, have they?

No. I have though. I work for the factory, the income tax and the insurance already, that's enough for a bit. They rob you right, left and centre. After they've skinned you dry you get called up to the army and get shot to death.
That's how things are Arthur, no good going crackers over it. All you can do is go on working and hope that some day something good will turn up.
Yes, yes it's yours right enough. Haven't done aught like that with Jack for a couple of months or more - and I don't want to have it I can tell you that now!
Have you tried aught, took aught I mean.
Yes, some pills, they didn't work. 30 bob they cost me too, gone right down the drain.
God almighty.
He won't help you.
Come on, what you frightened at, kiss won't hurt you.
What do you think I am, I don't even know you.
Well give us a kiss and then you will.
No, get off! You men are all the same.
I'm different.
You don't look like that to me.
Well I am, I think you're a little cracker.

What do you think having a kid means? You're doped and sick for 9 months, your clothes don't fit, nobody will look at you. One day you're yelling out and you've got a kid. That's not so bad but you've got to look after it for the rest of its life. You want to try it sometime.
Well if that's how you feel.
How do you expect me to feel?
Since when's he been your young man?
Not long.
He looks a bit rough if you ask me.
Oh he's all right.
Well you don't know him yet, do you?
Not like you know him I don't suppose.
Well, anyway, I like him.
Look I'll go and see me Aunt Ada, she'll know what to do, she's had 14 kids of her own and I'm sure she's got rid of as many others.
Did you get anywhere?
No, you?
Nah, that Betty's barmy, she wouldn't let me get near her. Tell you, you've got to marry them these days before you get aught.
Not if they're already married.
I thought I'd come and see you, I'm a bit worried about something.
Why, what would a good-looking chap like you have to worry about?
It's not that I'm worried Aunt Ada, I never worry - you know that. But it's this mate of mine at work, he's got a young woman in trouble and he don't know what to do about it.
That's a daft thing to do, couldn't he have been a bit more careful? Well he'll just have to face the music like our Dave did. Give me that kettle.
But isn't there something as can be done, I mean sometimes people get rid of it by taking things don't they?
What do you know about that?
I read about it in Sunday papers.
I'll clout you one of these days!
Ta'ra fatty.
What's the matter with you tonight?
I'll tell you what's the matter with me Arthur, I'm pregnant, good and proper this time - and it's your fault.
Oh aye, it's bound to be my fault isn't it.
Well of course it is, you never take care, you just don't bother, always said this would happen one day.
What a wonderful Friday night.
It's you, in't it, it's you as is in trouble.
Well it is if you want to know
I once knew a woman who got sent to prison for doing something like that. I'm sure I don't know what to tell you.
I thought you'd be able to help me.
Thougth I'd be able to help you just like that. You brainless loon, you ought to have more bloody sense, can't expect to get out of fixes as easy as that.
I've got nobody else to turn to.
Why don't you marry her if she's a nice girl.
She's already married.
You are in a bloody fix aren't you.
Having a good time?
Not bad, I'm with some pals from work, had to come out or I'd go crackers, I've been worrying about you all week.
Well you can stop worrying.
Is it all right then, did you see that doctor?
Oh yeah, I went, I didn't stay.
What?
I've decided to have it and face whatever comes of it.
Why don't you leave him alone you old bag.
Cheeky young beggar!
You'll get 6 months in Lincoln.
Oh - let me go.
Walk off mate, nobody'll stop you.
Don't put ideas in his head or you'll be in trouble.
You shut your bleeding rathole ratface, what good's it gonna do you handing him over to coppers?
It ain't right is it, I think men get away with murder.
They do, don't they.
I don't know that much.
Don't be such a big 'ead - and get cracking so as I can talk to her. What's your name duck?
Brenda.
You know the girl at our firm?
Which one?
You know, Tina, the one in the photo.
What about her?
She got married yesterday, she looked ever so nice.
What was the bloke like, could you smell the drink? They must've been drunk to get married.
You're in a rotten mood today.
I lost 5 quid at the races.
Serves you right, you shouldn't waste your money.
It's not wasted, I enjoy betting.
I don't care what you do with your money, its naught to do with me.
Well, stop telling me off then.
I'm not telling you off, you don't think I'm bothered about you like that do you?
That's not what you said in the pictures just now.
You're a pig, bringing it up like that.
I don't know how that ratface could do a thing like that.
Cause she's a bitch and a whore, she's got no heart in her - she's a swivel-eyed git.
She wants pole-axing.
Some people would nark on their mother, we're living in a jungle - we are and all. That bloke was a spineless bastard though, he should've run.
Been 'ere long?
10 minutes, I was just looking at the lovely view.
Better come down to earth then, adn't you?
How did you go on at Aunt Ada's, it go off all right?

No it didn't, was just one of them old wive's tricks, she made me sit in a hot bath for 3 hours, had to drink a pint of gin. I'll never go through that again, it was terrible, I thought I was gonna die. And it didn't work.
Somebody told me the other day they'd seen you coming out of the pictures with a young girl.
It's a bloody lie then.
Do you think I'm daft Arthur? I can tell you don't go as much on me as you used to .
That isn't true Brenda, you know I like you a lot.
I know you do, you can see it a mile off.
Not my fault if you don't believe me, is it?
You know the trouble with you, you don't know the difference between right and wrong, and I don't think you ever will.
Maybe I won't, but I don't want anybody to teach me either.
You'll learn one day.
We'll see, but it's now that matters isn't it, we've still got to clear this mess up.
Why don't you ever take me where it's lively and there's plenty of people?
They'd bested me right enough. Still, I had me bit of fun. It ain't the first time I've been in a losing fight, won't be the last either I don't suppose.
This is a nice room, are all them clothes 'yorn.
Ah, just a few rags.
They must have cost you a pretty penny.
I get good wages.
What's it like outside?
It's a bit cold.
Not in bed it 'int, it's warm under all these blankets - come and try.
What do you take me for?
Well we're courting aren't we?
You might call it courting.

Your a nice girl Doreen, I like you a lot. I reckon you oughta stay with me for good so's that I don't get knocked down by any more horses. Trouble with me is I'm always bumping into things, it's not much of a paying game.
You'll have to watch where you're going then won't you.
Your mam takes all night to read the paper, does she read slow or is she looking a the adverts?
She reads every word. She loves her newspaper more than a book.
You were born dead lucky, weren't you.
You're too much of a troublemaker, Arthur, you should take things as they come and enjoy life.
I do enjoy life, just because I'm not like you don't think I don't.
I'll see you sometime.
Yeah.
You know I told you to lay off weeks ago, not that you took a blind bit of notice.
Well you've gotta enjoy yourself.
You've got to keep your feet on the ground as well.
I can't see much use in that. You see people settle down and before they know where they are they've kicked the bucket.
It ain't altogether like that.
No, I now. It would be though if you didn't watch it.
You won't tell anybody anything, will you?
Why should I? It pays to keep your trap shut. Sit down.
No it don't.
I've just told you, haven't I? I told you - I got run over with a horse and cart.
You are a liar.
There's a lot more in life Bert, than me Mam and dad have got.
I asked mam if we could live at home, she said it'd be alright.
Till we get a new house, I wouldn't mind an old one me'self.
I would, I want a new one with a bathroom and everything.
I got beat up with 2 soldiers.
What for?
Well I've been knocking around with a married woman and her husband set them onto me, 2 onto 1, so they beat me. I'dve flattened them if they'd been one at a time.
I've still got some fight left in me, not like most people.
Not saying you ain't, but where does all this fighting get you?
Have you ever seen where not fighting's got you?
What are you doing round this way then?
I'm just going to press shop, I'm, I'm on days now.
I thought you might have been coming to see me.
There's no need of that is there?
In't there. Haven't you thought them squaddies had killed me.
I don't know what you're talking about.
I didn't think you would. That's the sort of bloke you are, in't it, till you get bashed in the face then you squeal like a stuck pig.
You caused a lot of trouble between me and Brenda, you can't deny it neither, it weren't right.
You don't have to tell me what's right and what isn't. How's Brenda anyway?
